t: Job 1
Job and His Family
There*p was a man in the country of Uz named Job. He was a man of complete integrity, who feared God and turned away from evil.
He had seven sons and three daughters.

His estate included seven thousand sheep and goats, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very large number of servants. Job was the greatest man among all the people of the east.
His*p sons used to take turns having banquets at their homes. They would send an invitation to their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

Whenever a round of banqueting was over, Job would send for his children and purify them, rising early in the morning to offer burnt offerings for all of them. For Job thought, “Perhaps my children have sinned, having cursed God in their hearts.” This was Job’s regular practice.
Satan’s First Test of Job
One*p day the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came with them.
The Lord*s asked Satan, “Where have you come from?” “From*p roaming through the earth,” Satan answered him, “and walking around on it.”
Then*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? No one else on earth is like him, a man of perfect integrity, who fears God and turns away from evil.”
Satan*p answered the Lord,*s “Does Job fear God for nothing?
Haven’t you placed a hedge around him, his household, and everything he owns? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
But stretch out your hand and strike everything he owns, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
“Very*p well,” the Lord*s told Satan, “everything he owns is in your power. However, do not lay a hand on Job himself.” So Satan left the Lord’s*s presence.
One*p day when Job’s sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
a messenger came to Job and reported, “While the oxen were plowing and the donkeys grazing nearby,
the Sabeans swooped down and took them away. They struck down the servants with the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
He*p was still speaking when another messenger came and reported, “God’s fire fell from heaven. It burned the sheep and the servants and devoured them, and I alone have escaped to tell you!”

That*p messenger was still speaking when yet another came and reported, “The Chaldeans formed three bands, made a raid on the camels, and took them away. They struck down the servants with the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
He*p was still speaking when another messenger came and reported, “Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house.
Suddenly a powerful wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on the young people so that they died, and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
Then*p Job stood up, tore his robe, and shaved his head. He fell to the ground and worshiped,
saying: Naked*pn I came from my mother’s womb, and*ln naked I will leave this life. The*ln Lord*s gives, and the Lord*s takes away. Blessed*ln be the name of the Lord.*s
Throughout*p all this Job did not sin or blame God for anything.
Job 2
Satan’s Second Test of Job
One*p day the sons of God came again to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came with them to present himself before the Lord.*s
The Lord*s asked Satan, “Where have you come from?” “From*p roaming through the earth,” Satan answered him, “and walking around on it.”

Then*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? No one else on earth is like him, a man of perfect integrity, who fears God and turns away from evil. He still retains his integrity, even though you incited me against him, to destroy him for no good reason.”
“Skin*p for skin!” Satan answered the Lord.*s “A man will give up everything he owns in exchange for his life.
But stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
“Very*p well,” the Lord*s told Satan, “he is in your power; only spare his life.”
So Satan left the Lord’s*s presence and infected Job with terrible boils from the soles of his feet to the top of his head.
Then Job took a piece of broken pottery to scrape himself while he sat among the ashes.
His*p wife said to him, “Are you still holding on to your integrity? Curse God and die!”
“You*p speak as a foolish woman speaks,” he told her. “Should we accept only good from God and not adversity?” Throughout all this Job did not sin in what he said.
Job’s Three Friends

Now*p when Job’s three friends - Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite - heard about all this adversity that had happened to him, each of them came from his home. They met together to go and sympathize with him and comfort him.
When they looked from a distance, they could barely recognize him. They wept aloud, and each man tore his robe and threw dust into the air and on his head.
Then they sat on the ground with him seven days and nights, but no one spoke a word to him because they saw that his suffering was very intense.
Job 3
Job’s Opening Speech
After*p this, Job began to speak and cursed the day he was born.
He said:
May*pn the day I was born perish, and*ln the night that said, “A*ln boy is conceived.”
If*ln only that day had turned to darkness! May*ln God above not care about it, or*ln light shine on it.
May*ln darkness and gloom reclaim it, and*ln a cloud settle over it. May*ln what darkens the day terrify it.
If*ln only darkness had taken that night away! May*ln it not appear among the days of the year or*ln be listed in the calendar.
Yes,*ln may that night be barren; may*ln no joyful shout be heard in it.
Let*ln those who curse days condemn*ln it, those*ln who are ready to rouse Leviathan.
May*ln its morning stars grow dark. May*ln it wait for daylight but have none; may*ln it not see the breaking of dawn.
For*ln that night did not shut the*ln doors of my mother’s womb, and*ln hide sorrow from my eyes.
Why*pn was I not stillborn; why*ln didn’t I die as I came from the womb?
Why*ln did the knees receive me, and*ln why were there breasts for me to nurse?
Now*ln I would certainly be lying down in peace; I*ln would be asleep. Then*ln I would be at rest
with*ln the kings and counselors of the earth, who*ln rebuilt ruined cities for themselves,
or*ln with princes who had gold, who*ln filled their houses with silver.
Or*ln why was I not hidden like a miscarried child, like*ln infants who never see daylight?
There*ln the wicked cease to make trouble, and*ln there the weary find rest.
The*ln captives are completely at rest; they*ln do not hear a taskmaster’s voice.
Both*ln small and great are there, and*ln the slave is set free from his master.
Why*pn is light given to one burdened with grief, and*ln life to those whose existence is bitter,
who*ln wait for death, but it does not come, and*ln search for it more than for hidden treasure,
who*ln are filled with much joy and*ln are glad when they reach the grave?
Why*ln is life given to a man whose path is hidden, whom*ln God has hedged in?
I*ln sigh when food is put before me, and*ln my groans pour out like water.
For*ln the thing I feared has overtaken me, and*ln what I dreaded has happened to me.
I*ln cannot relax or be calm; I*ln have no rest, for turmoil has come.
First Series of Speeches
Job 4
Eliphaz Speaks
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
Should*pn anyone try to speak with you when*ln you are exhausted? Yet*ln who can keep from speaking?
Indeed,*ln you have instructed many and*ln have strengthened weak hands.
Your*ln words have steadied the one who was stumbling and*ln braced the knees that were buckling.
But*ln now that this has happened to you, you*ln have become exhausted. It*ln strikes you, and you are dismayed.
Isn’t*ln your piety your confidence, and*ln the integrity of your life your hope?
Consider:*ln Who has perished when he was innocent? Where*ln have the honest been destroyed?
In*ln my experience, those who plow injustice and*ln those who sow trouble reap the same.
They*ln perish at a single blast from God and*ln come to an end by the breath of his nostrils.
The*ln lion may roar and the fierce lion growl, but*ln the teeth of young lions are broken.
The*ln strong lion dies if it catches no prey, and*ln the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
A*pn word was brought to me in secret; my*ln ears caught a whisper of it.
Among*ln unsettling thoughts from visions in the night, when*ln deep sleep comes over men,
fear*ln and trembling came over me and*ln made all my bones shake.
I*ln felt a draft on my face, and*ln the hair on my body stood up.
A*ln figure stood there, but*ln I could not recognize its appearance; a*ln form loomed before my eyes. I*ln heard a whispering voice:
“Can*ln a mortal be righteous before God? Can*ln a man be more pure than his Maker?”
If*ln God puts no trust in his servants and*ln he charges his angels with foolishness,
how*ln much more those who dwell in clay houses, whose*ln foundation is in the dust, who*ln are crushed like a moth!
They*ln are smashed to pieces from dawn to dusk; they*ln perish forever while no one notices.
Are*ln their tent cords not pulled up? They*ln die without wisdom.
Job 5
Call*pn out! Will anyone answer you? Which*ln of the holy ones will you turn to?
For*ln anger kills a fool, and*ln jealousy slays the gullible.
I*ln have seen a fool taking root, but*ln I immediately pronounced a curse on his home.
His*ln children are far from safety. They*ln are crushed at the city gate, with*ln no one to rescue them.
The*ln hungry consume his harvest, even*ln taking it out of the thorns. The*ln thirsty pant for his children’s wealth.
For*ln distress does not grow out of the soil, and*ln trouble does not sprout from the ground.
But*ln humans are born for trouble as*ln surely as sparks fly upward.
However,*pn if I were you, I would appeal to God and*ln would present my case to him.
He*ln does great and unsearchable things, wonders*ln without number.
He*ln gives rain to the earth and*ln sends water to the fields.
He*ln sets the lowly on high, and*ln mourners are lifted to safety.
He*ln frustrates the schemes of the crafty so*ln that they achieve no success.
He*ln traps the wise in their craftiness so*ln that the plans of the deceptive are*ln quickly brought to an end.
They*ln encounter darkness by day, and*ln they grope at noon as*ln if it were night.
He*ln saves the needy from their sharp words and*ln from the clutches of the powerful.
So*ln the poor have hope, and*ln injustice shuts its mouth.
See*ln how happy is the person whom God corrects; so*ln do not reject the discipline of the Almighty.
For*ln he wounds but he also bandages; he*ln strikes, but his hands also heal.
He*ln will rescue you from six calamities; no*ln harm will touch you in seven.
In*ln famine he will redeem you from death, and*ln in battle, from the power of the sword.
You*ln will be safe from slander and*ln not fear destruction when it comes.
You*ln will laugh at destruction and hunger and*ln not fear the land’s wild creatures.
For*ln you will have a covenant with the stones of the field, and*ln the wild animals will be at peace with you.
You*ln will know that your tent is secure, and*ln nothing will be missing when you inspect your home.
You*ln will also know that your offspring will be many and*ln your descendants like the grass of the earth.
You*ln will approach the grave in full vigor, as*ln a stack of sheaves is gathered in its season.
We*pn have investigated this, and it is true! Hear*ln it and understand it for yourself.
Job 6
Job’s Reply to Eliphaz
Then*p Job answered:
If*pn only my grief could be weighed and*ln my devastation placed with it on the scales.
For*ln then it would outweigh the sand of the seas! That*ln is why my words are rash.
Surely*ln the arrows of the Almighty have pierced me; my*ln spirit drinks their poison. God’s*ln terrors are arrayed against me.
Does*ln a wild donkey bray over fresh grass or*ln an ox low over its fodder?
Is*ln bland food eaten without salt? Is*ln there flavor in an egg white?
I*ln refuse to touch them; they*ln are like contaminated food.
If*pn only my request would be granted and*ln God would provide what I hope for:
that*ln he would decide to crush me, to*ln unleash his power and cut me off!
It*ln would still bring me comfort, and*ln I would leap for joy in unrelenting pain that*ln I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
What*pn strength do I have, that I should continue to hope? What*ln is my future, that I should be patient?
Is*ln my strength that of stone, or*ln my flesh made of bronze?
Since*ln I cannot help myself, the*ln hope for success has been banished from me.
A*pn despairing man should receive loyalty from his friends, even*ln if he abandons the fear of the Almighty.
My*ln brothers are as treacherous as a wadi, as*ln seasonal streams that overflow
and*ln become darkened because of ice, and*ln the snow melts into them.
The*ln wadis evaporate in warm weather; they*ln disappear from their channels in hot weather.
Caravans*ln turn away from their routes, go*ln up into the desert, and perish.
The*ln caravans of Tema look for these streams. The*ln traveling merchants of Sheba hope for them.
They*ln are ashamed because they had been confident of finding water. When*ln they arrive there, they are disappointed.
So*ln this is what you have now become to me. When*ln you see something dreadful, you are afraid.
Have*ln I ever said, “Give me something” or*ln “Pay a bribe for me from your wealth”
or*ln “Deliver me from the enemy’s hand” or*ln “Redeem me from the hand of the ruthless”?
Teach*pn me, and I will be silent. Help*ln me understand what I did wrong.
How*ln painful honest words can be! But*ln what does your rebuke prove?
Do*ln you think that you can disprove my words or*ln that a despairing man’s words are mere wind?
No*ln doubt you would cast lots for a fatherless child and*ln negotiate a price to sell your friend.
But*pn now, please look at me; I*ln will not lie to your face.
Reconsider;*ln don’t be unjust. Reconsider;*ln my righteousness is still the issue.
Is*ln there injustice on my tongue or*ln can my palate not taste disaster?
Job 7
Isn’t*pn each person consigned to forced labor on earth? Are*ln not his days like those of a hired worker?
Like*ln a slave he longs for shade; like*ln a hired worker he waits for his pay.
So*ln I have been made to inherit months of futility, and*ln troubled nights have been assigned to me.
When*ln I lie down I think, “When*ln will I get up?” But*ln the evening drags on endlessly, and*ln I toss and turn until dawn.
My*ln flesh is clothed with maggots and encrusted with dirt. My*ln skin forms scabs and then oozes.
My*pn days pass more swiftly than a weaver’s shuttle; they*ln come to an end without hope.
Remember*ln that my life is but a breath. My*ln eye will never again see anything good.
The*ln eye of anyone who looks on me will*ln no longer see me. Your*ln eyes will look for me, but I will be gone.
As*ln a cloud fades away and vanishes, so*ln the one who goes down to Sheol will never rise again.
He*ln will never return to his house; his*ln hometown will no longer remember him.
Therefore*pn I will not restrain my mouth. I*ln will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I*ln will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am*ln I the sea or a sea monster, that*ln you keep me under guard?
When*ln I say, “My bed will comfort me, and*ln my couch will ease my complaint,”
then*ln you frighten me with dreams, and*ln terrify me with visions,
so*ln that I prefer strangling— death*ln rather than life in this body.
I*ln give up! I will not live forever. Leave*ln me alone, for my days are a breath.
What*pn is a mere human, that you think so highly of him and*ln pay so much attention to him?
You*ln inspect him every morning, and*ln put him to the test every moment.
Will*ln you ever look away from me, or*ln leave me alone long enough to swallow?
If*ln I have sinned, what have I done to you, Watcher*ln of humanity? Why*ln have you made me your target, so*ln that I have become a burden to you?
Why*ln not forgive my sin and*ln pardon my iniquity? For*ln soon I will lie down in the grave. You*ln will eagerly seek me, but I will be gone.
Job 8
Bildad Speaks
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite replied:
How*pn long will you go on saying these things? Your*ln words are a blast of wind.
Does*ln God pervert justice? Does*ln the Almighty pervert what is right?
Since*ln your children sinned against him, he*ln gave them over to their rebellion.
But*ln if you earnestly seek God and*ln ask the Almighty for mercy,
if*ln you are pure and upright, then*ln he will move even now on your behalf and*ln restore the home where your righteousness dwells.
Then,*ln even if your beginnings were modest, your*ln final days will be full of prosperity.
For*pn ask the previous generation, and*ln pay attention to what their ancestors discovered,
since*ln we were born only yesterday and know nothing. Our*ln days on earth are but a shadow.
Will*ln they not teach you and tell you and*ln speak from their understanding?
Does*ln papyrus grow where there is no marsh? Do*ln reeds flourish without water?
While*ln still uncut shoots, they*ln would dry up quicker than any other plant.
Such*ln is the destiny of all who forget God; the*ln hope of the godless will perish.
His*pn source of confidence is fragile; what*ln he trusts in is a spider’s web.
He*ln leans on his web, but it doesn’t stand firm. He*ln grabs it, but it does not hold up.
He*ln is a well-watered plant in the sunshine; his*ln shoots spread out over his garden.
His*ln roots are intertwined around a pile of rocks. He*ln looks for a home among the stones.
If*ln he is uprooted from his place, it*ln will deny knowing him, saying, “I never saw you.”
Surely*ln this is the joy of his way of life; yet*ln others will sprout from the dust.
Look,*ln God does not reject a person of integrity, and*ln he will not support evildoers.
He*pn will yet fill your mouth with laughter and*ln your lips with a shout of joy.
Your*ln enemies will be clothed with shame; the*ln tent of the wicked will no longer exist.
Job 9
Job’s Reply to Bildad
Then*p Job answered:
Yes,*pn I know what you’ve said is true, but*ln how can a person be justified before God?
If*ln one wanted to take him to court, he*ln could not answer God once in a thousand times.
God*ln is wise and all-powerful. Who*ln has opposed him and come out unharmed?
He*ln removes mountains without their knowledge, overturning*ln them in his anger.
He*ln shakes the earth from its place so*ln that its pillars tremble.
He*ln commands the sun not to shine and*ln seals off the stars.
He*ln alone stretches out the heavens and*ln treads on the waves of the sea.
He*ln makes the stars: the Bear, Orion, the*ln Pleiades, and the constellations of the southern sky.
He*ln does great and unsearchable things, wonders*ln without number.
If*ln he passed by me, I wouldn’t see him; if*ln he went by, I wouldn’t recognize him.
If*ln he snatches something, who can stop him? Who*ln can ask him, “What are you doing?”
God*ln does not hold back his anger; Rahab’s*ln assistants cringe in fear beneath him!
How*ln then can I answer him or*ln choose my arguments against him?
Even*ln if I were in the right, I could not answer. I*ln could only beg my Judge for mercy.
If*ln I summoned him and he answered me, I*ln do not believe he would pay attention to what I said.
He*ln batters me with a whirlwind and*ln multiplies my wounds without cause.
He*ln doesn’t let me catch my breath but*ln fills me with bitter experiences.
If*ln it is a matter of strength, look, he is the powerful one! If*ln it is a matter of justice, who can summon him?
Even*ln if I were in the right, my own mouth would condemn me; if*ln I were blameless, my mouth would declare me guilty.
Though*ln I am blameless, I*ln no longer care about myself; I*ln renounce my life.
It*ln is all the same. Therefore I say, “He*ln destroys both the blameless and the wicked.”
When*ln catastrophe brings sudden death, he*ln mocks the despair of the innocent.
The*ln earth is handed over to the wicked; he*ln blindfolds its judges. If*ln it isn’t he, then who is it?
My*pn days fly by faster than a runner; they*ln flee without seeing any good.
They*ln sweep by like boats made of papyrus, like*ln an eagle swooping down on its prey.
If*ln I said, “I will forget my complaint, change*ln my expression, and smile,”
I*ln would still live in terror of all my pains. I*ln know you will not acquit me.
Since*ln I will be found guilty, why*ln should I struggle in vain?
If*ln I wash myself with snow, and*ln cleanse my hands with lye,
then*ln you dip me in a pit of mud, and*ln my own clothes despise me!
For*pn he is not a man like me, that I can answer him, that*ln we can take each other to court.
There*ln is no mediator between us, to*ln lay his hand on both of us.
Let*ln him take his rod away from me so*ln his terror will no longer frighten me.
Then*ln I would speak and not fear him. But*ln that is not the case; I am on my own.
Job 10
I*pn am disgusted with my life. I*ln will give vent to my complaint and*ln speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ln will say to God, “Do*ln not declare me guilty! Let*ln me know why you prosecute me.
Is*ln it good for you to oppress, to*ln reject the work of your hands, and*ln favor the plans of the wicked?
Do*ln you have eyes of flesh, or*ln do you see as a human sees?
Are*ln your days like those of a human, or*ln your years like those of a man,
that*ln you look for my iniquity and*ln search for my sin,
even*ln though you know that I am not wicked and*ln that there is no one who can rescue from your power?
“Your*pn hands shaped me and formed me. Will*ln you now turn and destroy me?
Please*ln remember that you formed me like clay. Will*ln you now return me to dust?
Did*ln you not pour me out like milk and*ln curdle me like cheese?
You*ln clothed me with skin and flesh, and*ln wove me together with bones and tendons.
You*ln gave me life and faithful love, and*ln your care has guarded my life.
“Yet*pn you concealed these thoughts in your heart; I*ln know that this was your hidden plan:
if*ln I sin, you would notice, and*ln would not acquit me of my iniquity.
If*ln I am wicked, woe to me! And*ln even if I am righteous, I cannot lift up my head. I*ln am filled with shame and*ln have drunk deeply of my affliction.
If*ln I am proud, you hunt me like a lion and*ln again display your miraculous power against me.
You*ln produce new witnesses against me and*ln multiply your anger toward me. Hardships*ln assault me, wave after wave.
“Why*pn did you bring me out of the womb? I*ln should have died and never been seen.
I*ln wish I had never existed but*ln had been carried from the womb to the grave.
Are*ln my days not few? Stop it! Leave*ln me alone, so that I can smile a little
before*ln I go to a land of darkness and gloom, never*ln to return.
It*ln is a land of blackness like the deepest darkness, gloomy*ln and chaotic, where*ln even the light is like the darkness.”
Job 11
Zophar Speaks
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite replied:
Should*pn this abundance of words go unanswered and*ln such a talker be acquitted?
Should*ln your babbling put others to silence, so*ln that you can keep on ridiculing with*ln no one to humiliate you?
You*ln have said, “My teaching is sound, and*ln I am pure in your sight.”
But*ln if only God would speak and*ln open his lips against you!
He*ln would show you the secrets of wisdom, for*ln true wisdom has two sides. Know*ln then that God has chosen to overlook some of your iniquity.
Can*pn you fathom the depths of God or*ln discover the limits of the Almighty?
They*ln are higher than the heavens - what can you do? They*ln are deeper than Sheol - what can you know?
Their*ln measure is longer than the earth and*ln wider than the sea.
If*pn he passes by and throws someone in prison or*ln convenes a court, who can stop him?
Surely*ln he knows which people are worthless. If*ln he sees iniquity, will he not take note of it?
But*ln a stupid person will gain understanding as*ln soon as a wild donkey is born a human!
As*pn for you, if you redirect your heart and*ln spread out your hands to him in prayer —
if*ln there is iniquity in your hand, remove it, and*ln don’t allow injustice to dwell in your tents —
then*ln you will hold your head high, free from fault. You*ln will be firmly established and unafraid.
For*ln you will forget your suffering, recalling*ln it only as water that has flowed by.
Your*ln life will be brighter than noonday; its*ln darkness will be like the morning.
You*ln will be confident, because there is hope. You*ln will look carefully about and lie down in safety.
You*pn will lie down with no one to frighten you, and*ln many will seek your favor.
But*ln the sight of the wicked will fail. Their*ln way of escape will be cut off, and*ln their only hope is their last breath.
Job 12
Job’s Reply to Zophar
Then*p Job answered:
No*pn doubt you are the people, and*ln wisdom will die with you!
But*ln I also have a mind like you; I*ln am not inferior to you. Who*ln doesn’t know the things you are talking about?
I*pn am a laughingstock to my friends, by*ln calling on God, who answers me. The*ln righteous and blameless man is a laughingstock.
The*ln one who is at ease holds calamity in contempt and*ln thinks it is prepared for those whose feet are slipping.
The*ln tents of robbers are safe, and*ln those who trouble God are secure; God*ln holds them in his hands.
But*pn ask the animals, and they will instruct you; ask*ln the birds of the sky, and they will tell you.
Or*ln speak to the earth, and it will instruct you; let*ln the fish of the sea inform you.
Which*ln of all these does not know that*ln the hand of the Lord*s has done this?
The*ln life of every living thing is in his hand, as*ln well as the breath of all humanity.
Doesn’t*ln the ear test words as*ln the palate tastes food?
Wisdom*ln is found with the elderly, and*ln understanding comes with long life.
Wisdom*pn and strength belong to God; counsel*ln and understanding are his.
Whatever*ln he tears down cannot be rebuilt; whoever*ln he imprisons cannot be released.
When*ln he withholds water, everything dries up, and*ln when he releases it, it destroys the land.
True*ln wisdom and power belong to him. The*ln deceived and the deceiver are his.
He*ln leads counselors away barefoot and*ln makes judges go mad.
He*ln releases the bonds put on by kings and*ln fastens a belt around their waists.
He*ln leads priests away barefoot and*ln overthrows established leaders.
He*ln deprives trusted advisers of speech and*ln takes away the elders’ good judgment.
He*ln pours out contempt on nobles and*ln disarms the strong.
He*ln reveals mysteries from the darkness and*ln brings the deepest darkness into the light.
He*ln makes nations great, then destroys them; he*ln enlarges nations, then leads them away.
He*ln deprives the world’s leaders of reason, and*ln makes them wander in a trackless wasteland.
They*ln grope around in darkness without light; he*ln makes them stagger like a drunkard.
Job 13
Look,*pn my eyes have seen all this; my*ln ears have heard and understood it.
Everything*ln you know, I also know; I*ln am not inferior to you.
Yet*ln I prefer to speak to the Almighty and*ln argue my case before God.
You*ln use lies like plaster; you*ln are all worthless healers.
If*ln only you would shut up and*ln let that be your wisdom!
Hear*pn now my argument, and*ln listen to my defense.
Would*ln you testify unjustly on God’s behalf or*ln speak deceitfully for him?
Would*ln you show partiality to him or*ln argue the case in his defense?
Would*ln it go well if he examined you? Could*ln you deceive him as you would deceive a man?
Surely*ln he would rebuke you if*ln you secretly showed partiality.
Would*ln God’s majesty not terrify you? Would*ln his dread not fall on you?
Your*ln memorable sayings are proverbs of ash; your*ln defenses are made of clay.
Be*pn quiet, and I will speak. Let*ln whatever comes happen to me.
I*ln will put myself at risk and*ln take my life in my own hands.
Even*ln if he kills me, I will hope in him. I*ln will still defend my ways before him.
Yes,*ln this will result in my deliverance, for*ln no godless person can appear before him.
Pay*ln close attention to my words; let*ln my declaration ring in your ears.
